name: Islamic Center of Irvine
mission: Mission statement - To establish a comprehensive center promoting Islamic values and reflecting excellence in serving the needs of the community
zakatClaimEvidence: 100% of the Islamic Center Of Irvine's Zakat fund goes towards providing zakat eligible members in the community. If you would like to contribute funds to help needy families you can do so by either donating your Zakat ul-Maal or your Sadaqah. (Source: https://icoi.net/donate)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.evidence: Explicit zakat program (+4); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

alignment.rationale: Alignment 21/50: MEDIUM Muslim donor fit, religious cultural cause area

components.evidence: No beneficiary data available for cost-per-beneficiary scoring; high program ratio (≥85%) suggests efficient delivery
components.improvement_suggestion: Publish beneficiary counts consistently so cost-effectiveness can be assessed.
components.name: Cost Per Beneficiary

components.improvement_suggestion: If reserves are above policy target, document why and publish triggers for planned deployment.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Seek external evaluation or track outcomes over at least 3 years.
components.name: Evidence & Outcomes

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

judge_issues.message: ZAKAT-ELIGIBLE claimed but no explicit zakat evidence found on website
Evaluation source domain 'projects.propublica.org' is not a known trusted evaluator
Evaluation source domain 'feelingblessed.org' is not a known trusted evaluator

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Islamic Center of Irvine Inc shows moderate impact and moderate alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

If you would like to contribute funds to help needy families you can do so by either donating your Zakat ul-Maal or your Sadaqah. (Source: https://icoi.net/donate)

all_citations.claim: The organization reports a total revenue of $2,209,994 and focuses on capacity-building within the religious and cultural sector.
Financial records show a program expense ratio of 89.9%, working capital of 26.3 months, and fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised.
The organization offers various donation options and is identified as zakat-eligible.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to excellent internal financial management and efficiency, balanced by a lack of external impact verification and a focus on localized religious services.
areas_for_improvement: Limited third-party impact data or external performance evaluations
Moderate alignment with broader donor urgency metrics compared to humanitarian-focused peers

dimension_explanations.alignment: Alignment is rated at 21/50, reflecting a medium donor fit for those specifically seeking religious and cultural engagement [1]. The organization is confirmed as zakat-eligible, providing a critical giving pathway for Muslim donors, though its cause urgency is categorized as religious/cultural rather than emergency-based [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates a moderate impact score of 26/50, characterized by a capacity-building directness that focuses on community infrastructure [1]. While financial health is strong with an 89.9% program expense ratio, the lack of specific cost-per-beneficiary data limits a higher effectiveness rating [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc serves as a comprehensive community hub dedicated to promoting Islamic values through robust social and professional programming.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 89.9%, indicating the vast majority of funds go directly to services
Exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 26.3 months of working capital available
baseline_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc (ICOI) operates with a mission to serve community needs through excellence and Islamic values, reporting a total revenue of $2,209,994 [1][2]. The organization facilitates various community initiatives, including 'The Village In Irvine' and 'ICOI Young Professionals,' while maintaining zakat-eligible status for donors [2][3].

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization earns a moderate overall score due to excellent internal financial management and efficiency, balanced by a lack of external impact verification and a focus on localized religious services.

areas_for_improvement.context: There is currently <cite id="14">no publicly available beneficiary data</cite> or external impact evaluation, making it difficult to assess the cost-effectiveness of specific programs.
The organization lacks a <cite id="15">documented theory of change</cite>, which would help donors understand the long-term causal pathway of its community interventions.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization is not currently evaluated by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization's strong financial health and high program ratio suggest that funds are being utilized for their intended purposes despite the lack of formal impact reporting.
risk_factors: <cite id="15">Lack of a formal theory of change</cite>
case_against.summary: The primary concern is the <cite id="14">absence of rigorous impact data</cite> and external evaluations common in larger humanitarian organizations.

confidence.notes: Strong financial transparency but limited impact documentation.

alignment.explanation: The organization is a strong fit for local donors, offering <cite id="18">verified zakat-eligible giving</cite> for categories such as the poor (fuqara) and needy (masakin).
alignment.improvement: Clarifying the <cite id="18">specific zakat allocation policy</cite> would help donors understand exactly how their obligatory charity is distributed across the eight asnaf.

credibility.explanation: Donors can find confidence in the center's <cite id="12">100% independent board</cite> and its <cite id="16">Bronze Seal of Transparency from Candid</cite>. The organization also maintains <cite id="17">total assets of $4,874,051</cite> against minimal liabilities.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the organization should <cite id="14">publish annual impact reports</cite> that include specific beneficiary counts and audited financial statements.

impact.explanation: Impact is driven by a <cite id="4">high program expense ratio of 89.9%</cite> and a capacity-building model. However, the <cite id="14">lack of cost-per-beneficiary data</cite> limits the ability to measure absolute effectiveness.
impact.improvement: The center should <cite id="15">document a clear theory of change</cite> and begin tracking longitudinal outcomes for its youth and professional programs.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Financial transparency without outcome tracking

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Supports regional Islamic educational and community organizations

rich_narrative.headline: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc serves as a comprehensive community hub dedicated to promoting Islamic values through robust social and professional programming.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors in Southern California who want to invest in local Islamic community infrastructure and professional development through a fiscally lean organization.
donor_motivations: Want to support local Muslim community growth in Orange County
Value high financial efficiency and low overhead
Prefer organizations that serve as community hubs for youth and professionals
Looking for zakat-eligible local giving options
giving_considerations: Donations support a regional center rather than international relief
Impact is measured through community presence rather than RCT-level data
High liquidity suggests the organization is in a stable, long-term growth phase
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-rigor academic evidence of impact or those focused exclusively on international humanitarian crises.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects strong financial transparency and program ratios, but a <cite id="14">lack of verified outcome metrics</cite>.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: ICOI creates impact by providing religious, social, and professional spaces that strengthen Islamic identity and community cohesion in Irvine.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence helps ensure that community programs are effectively meeting the spiritual and social needs of the congregation.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With a <cite id="13">10.6% revenue growth rate</cite> and expanding programs like The Village, the center has capacity to scale its local services.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by an <cite id="5">exceptional $0.00 fundraising cost</cite> and significant grantmaking activity to other Islamic institutions.

strengths.detail: The organization directs <cite id="4">89.9% of its total expenses</cite> toward its core programs and services, far exceeding standard efficiency benchmarks for religious non-profits.
ICOI reports <cite id="5">spending $0.00 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions, suggesting a highly organic and community-driven support base.
The center maintains <cite id="8">26.3 months of working capital</cite> in working capital, providing a significant buffer against economic volatility.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Center of Irvine demonstrates a sophisticated financial structure for a community-based organization. Its revenue is diversified across <cite id="9">$1,944,081 in direct contributions</cite> and <cite id="10">$206,424 in program service revenue</cite>, indicating that its community offerings also generate sustainable earned income. Governance is a notable strength, with a <cite id="11">board of 9 members</cite> where <cite id="12">100% are independent</cite>, ensuring objective oversight of the center's mission and assets. This governance structure supports a wide array of activities, from <cite id="2">Ramadan programs to a local business directory</cite>, all while maintaining a <cite id="13">3-year revenue CAGR of 10.6%</cite>, reflecting steady institutional growth.
rich_narrative.summary: The Islamic Center of Irvine Inc (ICOI) serves as a vital community anchor in Orange County, California, dedicated to <cite id="1">promoting Islamic values and reflecting excellence</cite> in its service delivery. The organization manages a diverse portfolio of social and professional initiatives, including <cite id="2">The Village In Irvine and ICOI Young Professionals</cite>, which cater to various demographic needs within the local Muslim population. Financially, the center operates at a significant scale for a regional religious institution, reporting <cite id="3">total revenue of $2,209,994</cite> in its most recent filings. A hallmark of its financial management is its high efficiency, with a <cite id="4">program expense ratio of 89.9%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of donor contributions directly support community services and religious programming. Furthermore, the organization demonstrates exceptional fiscal discipline in its development efforts, maintaining <cite id="5">fundraising efficiency of $0.00 per $1 raised</cite>. Beyond local programming, ICOI also acts as a philanthropic conduit, distributing <cite id="6">$31,500 in total grants</cite> to domestic partners, including the American Islamic Institute of AV and the Inland Valley Islamic Society. This dual role as both a direct service provider and a community grantmaker positions ICOI as a central pillar of the <cite id="7">Irvine and Orange County Islamic infrastructure</cite>.
